number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
Early Access Review
								Dungeon of the Endless is an interesting new title by Amplitude Studios currently in Alpha development which spans several popular genres.For my full featured review with pictures and videos coming soon please visit http://progamereviews.com/review/dungeon-endless/You begin Dungeon of the Endless with two hero characters and a crystal in a small escape pod. The basic premise of the game is to explore each dungeon and find the exit. Each dungeon is comprised of interconnected randomly generated rooms. Many of these rooms contain mobs of monsters that attempt to end your game by either killing your heroes or your crystal. As you explore the dungeon's rooms you acquire resources and have the ability use these resources to deploy defenses. Game play is actually a hybrid of real time and turn based strategy in that you have the ability to pause live game play and issue commands if you so desire. The game can also be played in real time mode exclusively. Once the exit is located, your job is to transport the crystal safely there. If you make it you win the round and move on to the next level. If your heroes die, you lose. If your crystal’s dust level (essentially health, power and currency all in one) falls to zero, you lose. Piece of cake right? WRONG.Dungeon of the Endless has a lot of things going on. At its heart, it is a rouge like (hate that term) dungeon crawler. You explore a procedurally generated environment with a small group of  playable heroes. What that means is this: the dungeons and encounters are never exactly the same. Sure you’ll see similarities, but by and large the environments will never be exactly alike. Additionally, your band of motley heroes isn’t invincible. Once they die, they’re dead… FOREVER. Kiss all that experience and loot goodbye! Rogue like game play; check.So what else does the game offer? How about some resource management? In Dungeon of the Endless your success or failure is largely linked to your resource acquisition and management. There are four main resources to worry about: Dust (no you can't snort it), Industry, Food and Science. Every time you open a room you receive an amount of each resource except dust. Additionally, you can deploy resource modules in powered rooms (more on that later) that add a modifier to the amount of a particular resources obtained when subsequent doors are opened. For example, an Industry module will provide additional industry every time you open a new door. Heroes with the required skill can even operate the module and provide an additional, additional bonus to the resources. Phew, that sounds complicated. Of note here is that extra resources, except dust, are carried over to the next dungeon.Dungeon of the Endless also has Role Playing and Character Progression aspects. Even though the game features permadeath you have the ability to level up your hero's and outfit them with gear discovered in dungeons. Your heroes have stats which increase as their levels increase. In addition, as you level up your heroes they gain access to special combat skills.But wait, there's more...Dungeon of the Endless also offers tower defense like game play. As you explore each dungeon level you "open up" additional parts of the map. Each new room traversed is dark, which means it is currently not powered. These darkened rooms serve as spawn points for mobs of monsters which attack in waves and make a beeline toward your crystal. How do you stop these waves of monsters you ask? Well, you power some of these dark rooms with part of your limited supply of dust. Once powered, you then use your Industry resource to build defenses. As waves of enemies appear, your smartly placed defenses and heroes take them out. Sounds kinda tower defense like huh.One of Amplitude Studios goals is community involvement. Amplitude wants the players to take an active part in the game's development and it is facilitating this by utilizing a system called GAMES2GETHER . One of the biggest reasons to play an early access game is to participate in the evolution of a game. Plenty of Steam early access games claim to use player feedback to help shape the final product into what the community wants... and then promptly don't. Amplitude appears to actually be following through with it. By utilizing it's G2G Votes system, the community has the ability to vote on art and game design decisions. For example, the current vote is for creating a new playable character. There is also a standard forum where players can follow the games development and post their questions and comments. The jury is still out on how much the community will drive development however so we'll have to monitor the process and see how it goes.Like every other game out there, Dungeon of the Endless is not perfect. I'll cover what I feel are weak points for the game first. The game needs a lot more explanation. This is a reasonably complex game and the current tutorial slides just don't cut it. I found myself with more questions than answers after the tutorial and had to stumble into them myself. A proper tutorial level guiding the player through the games nuisances would help to acclimate players better. As this is just the alpha stage, i'm sure the developers will address this in the near future. The graphics are basic. Again, this is by design but worth noting anyway.Another issue is repetitiveness. Although the levels are procedurally generated they all look and feel essentially the same. This in addition to the fact that the basic game play remains the same can make the game feel a bit tedious after a while.  Is there an end to the game or is it truly endless? I don't actually know the answer to that question. But if the game had milestones or varied locations to make you feel like your progressing it might help. Its worth noting that in general I usually don't play rogue like games specifically for this reason. As an old school RPG and MMORPG player, I tend to become attached to my characters and devote a good amount of time carefully picking their skills and equipment. The permadeath aspect of these games is a turn off for me. I like to feel that i'm making progress towards a larger goal and I just didn't feel it with this game.All that being said, I still really like the game. Dungeon of the Endless is a fun and reasonably deep game. What's most impressive is the games complexity despite its current Alpha state. There's enough depth and strategy here already to keep you playing the game and checking back to see how it evolves. Also, at this point in my life, I tend to be gravitating towards games that i can play in small chunks. Dungeon of the Endless gives players the ability to save and pause games at any time. If your a new parent like me, trying to juggle work, parenthood, and everything else life throws at you, this is HUGE. For the price of entry, Dungeon of the Endless is definitely forth a look.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 17, 2013
Early Access Review
								   What AMPLITUDE has here are most definitely the makings of a superb game.  The progression of opening doors to begin waves and shape the enemies' overall path is the perfect way to marriage the Tower Defense and Roguelike geres.  "What you'll find behind the door" is just random enough that you can experience "garbage runs", but it's balanced enough that a run is never doomed before it begins.   Risk and reward are balanced very well, too, often in the form of continuous decision making on the player's part: "Do I hunker down in this position, or do I spread out my defenses to guard more resource production?" "Do I pay Dust (resource that lasts only one floor) to a Merchant for items, possibly overextend my resources until I'm done with the floor (and Dust is less precious) or play it safe and make sure I can live to see the next level?"   There may only be three floors to the game as of now, but Dungeon of the Endless is already worth the price of admission if you're a fan of the genres.  And I have no doubt it will only get better from here.

												Insanely fun and challenging take on rogue likes. Tower defense elements are fun and challenging. Balancing which rooms to power up and strategically covering both your expansion and the thrilling final escape to the elevator with your crystal. Upgrade tree is great branching out to offer different weapons, buffs for heroes and upgrades. Can certainly be frustrating when you've explored an entire floor and you've missed a few rooms and get rolled by strong monsters but that's the name of the game with roguelikes right? Learn through dying. Haven't played the multiplayer yet but really looking forward to see how that changes the dynamic.

content:
er 13, 2013
Early Access Review
								One more door. Just one more door.I am not a huge fan of tower defense games, but this little rogue-like has me hooked. Beyond the simple build-and-defend mechanic at the heart of every TD, DotE adds a compelling risk-reward element in the choice between doubling down and heading to the exit with the resources you've collected, or opening one more door in hopes of finding treasure or an ally at the risk of multiple waves of enemies threatening to destroy everything you have built. Striking that balance is key to your survival.Dungeon of the Endless is still in its early stages, but this little monster has a lot of potential. More items, more enemies, more levels, more non-combat encounters, story elements, heroic side quests, and party management mechanics are sure to come, but I would love to see competing parties of survivors taking resources (multiplayer plix?), the ability to relock doors (albeit either as limited use item or heroic ability), and different environments (with more incredible music added to what is already a killer soundtrack).I cannot wait to see how this game develops. I am officially pumped.

content:
y 6, 2015
												If you like FTL you'll like this game.  It has elements of a lot of different types of games:  4x, Rogue-like, Tower Defense, etc.    The goal is to escape the dungeon floor by floor.    Each floor starts the same way, you and a power source.    You need to explore until you find the exit.   Then you need to plan a way to move the power source to the exit.   Moving said power source spawns a neverending slew of monsters.   Monsters spawn from unpowered areas so you can set up an escape route.   All the while you need to balance leveling your team (Food), researching modules (Science) and building defenses or resource generating modules.   I'm 0 for 7 on "Too Easy" so expect a challenge.

content:
y 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is very simple in its design but is incredibly well thought out in its execution. Randomly generated dungeons, resource management, multiple player characters, there is an incredible amount of depth and tactical feel to this game. The graphics and soundtrack make for a rather nostalgic feel instead of being outdated or lacking in their preformance they throw us back to old school titles that we used to know and love. This game feels like the developers are taking their time slowly but surely perfecting it, a nice change of pace from the games of today. Indie developers seem to have what big game companies have lost they are putting their heart and souls into this project and it shows Dungeon is an incredible game even in its alpha stages it has amazing potential. Those of you who bought the founders packs or might have helped kickstart it i feel like your faith will not go unrewarded. I only hope that future versions of the game might include harder difficulties, and maybe some lines of dialouge between heroes nothing voiced mind you but a few texts expressing the characters state of mind feelings towards one another or just jokes or comments about the dungeons themselves would be interesting, expanding the lore might also be cool finding codexes or data logs strewn about that contain information on the creatures crew ship and planet would be a fun treat for people who love to immerse themselves into the game. Though changes like that would be nice the game already offers so much in its alpha stage that i only imagine the completed product will be nothing less than amazing I give the alpha version of this game a 9/10 and I would say that this is my most anticapated title pending release and i absolutley can't wait for the final version I recomend anyone who reads this grab the founders pack as soon as possible you will not be dissapointed.

(Personal valuation 8/10)I must say this game may be an Alpha Version still - but it plays itself like a Full game.Random generated Maps and diffrent Characters each time make this game a great game to play when you are bored.But its not an easy one.The goal in this game is to bring your Energy-Crystal to the escape point, which will make you reach the next level - and thereby map of the game.Sounds easy? Wrong. The rooms you walk trough with your two start characters contain treasures, supplies or evil monsters which try to destroy your Crystal.Your Crystal can power rooms so no enemies spawn inside and so you can build defenses or generators. Every few rooms, some enemies spawn in dark rooms to attack your crystal.Will you find the exit and carry the crystal there, or will your enemies destroy you and your crystal?

ry 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								Dungeon of the Endless is a little abstract at first, but once you get the mechanics it's a unique RTS experience. Each room means choices, that will subtly effect the outcome. You can move the heros from room to room but once there, they automatically do their thing, and you can pause at any time to accomplish this positioning. As difficulty increases, more and more waves of enemies spawn out of dark, unpowered rooms.  There's lots of dying, over and over. The game is pretty hard, and sometimes you'll die more from bad luck than anything you did, but that's part of the random fun you get with each play thru. Still in Alpha, this game is a solid investment in value.

content:
er 15, 2013
Early Access Review
								(As of 0.1.1)It’s tough, and probably needs a little rebalancing as to where things spawn and how much, but being it's in alpha I'm extremely impressed. I made it through on my 5th or 6th try, at least as far as the early access would allow (level 4 I think?). I can tell I'm going to love this game though. The two negative things I have to say about it are that occasionally it'll seem a bit unfair and loot will only rarely spawn that you can use if you don’t have a diverse team (something you can't choose). Once I started a new game died after I opened the third door. There was nothing that I could have done to prevent this and was a clear case of the game killing me instead of me dying. Many times, starting out, you'll find that any gear you stumble across is only good to be sold since neither of your two people can use a pistol, for example  (despite one of them being able to use machine guns...?). Whether the latter issue is problem with the loot drops or the gear system is subjective I suppose.All that being said though, I love this game so far. I love the genre bending mechanics and the not-quite-shadowrun and not-quite-fallout world. I love the art and sound. I love the droplets of story you get with each random party and each piece of gear you stumble across. I cannot recommend this game enough.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 25, 2016
												Dungeon of the Endless is a tower defense game with rogue-like elements.  You control a squad of up to four characters as you try and make your way out of a 12-floor dungeon filled with monsters.  Those familiar with Amplitude's other games will recognize the resources you'll need to survive: industry for building, science for research, food for leveling up your squad members, and dust for powering rooms.  To generate these resources, you build modules, open doors, and fend off waves of monsters when they decide to attack your "core" (a giant crystal).  The rogue-like elements include perma-death (although you may find your dead character again in a later floor), random dungeon layouts, and randomness when it comes to opening doors.  Once you learn the game's mechanics, the game can get easy.  However, it is fun to play with friends and the "unstable" cast of characters makes things interesting as you learn about the lore.  The soundtrack and pixel art look of the game are excellent and extremely memorable.

content:
y 27, 2015
												TL;DR || The game is a fun mix of dungeon crawling RPG and tower defense. Perma-death, random dungeon layouts, and a good selection of characters add to the replay value. Multiple heroes to unlock. Level 'em up. Gear 'em up. Meet new heroes while in the dungeon and have them join your party. Find ancient treasure. Research new tech. Die, lose it all, and happily start over again. The devs are a pretty swell bunch too!!!I think the art style is fantastic, and the same can be said for the sound design and soundtrack. The gameplay is quite fluid with a nice interface and can also be quite challenging with a good bit a strategy mixed in. Clear the dungeon room by room using your heroes, while setting up defenses to protect your ship's power core. Once you find the floor's exit, defend one of your heroes as he slowly carries the core to the elevator. You can power up rooms to prevent enemies from spawning in them and use that power to set up turrets and resource nodes; this helps you create a defensible path to the elevator, because once you touch that core, they don't stop coming.The developers are worth mentioning too. AMPLITUDE is hands down one of my favorite studios. They put out quality products and continue to provide support for their games beyond their initial release.If you'd like to see a bit of gameplay:


YouTube™ Video:

content:
6, 2016
												[I've just beat all 12 floors of the first dungeon solo and on "Too Easy", see below. Tried many different heroes. Pixel Edition.] Remarkable game. Didn't think I would enjoy pixelated graphics, but apparently it doesn't look "bad" just because it doesn't look "realistic". The details in animation and environment are stunning. The dreamy soundtrack and amazing artstyle craft a unique, otherwordly atmosphere to enjoy this marvellous strategy adventure in. I will say that the difficulty settings are misleading - there are only Too Easy and Easy. You better plan what you're doing carefully on Too Easy if you mean to make it to the surface. Taking on Easy will be a daunting task for sure. Encountered about three bugs - an Item Duplicating bug in Multiplayer (beneficial), a frozen Hero in Multiplayer (easily resolved by restarting the game) and an Item Vanishing bug in both Single- and Multiplayer (once each)(rather frustrating). The excitement of exploring what's behind the next door is what makes this game truly addictive to me. Will be upgrading to Crystal Edition now to unlock some more heroes and challenges, but all you really need to get into the game and see if you like it is in the Pixel Edition. 9/10 - would buy again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 17, 2015
What do I rate it? A significantly high 7/10.Why?In brief; it's an amazing dungeon crawler with a tower-defense aspect seamlessly and cleverly incorporated into the fighting aspect of the game between each round of opening a new random door. You could trawl the floors for hours and spend even longer over-thinking your strategic moves between rooms. After the fourth or fifth floor, you begin to feel a familiarity building and the game slowly becomes a little repetitive. Discovering the same rooms you did two floors ago - like a treasure room, banquet surprise (food bonus), scrap parts (factory parts) and yadda yadda. So although the maps are all unique and no path is the same as the last map, you begin to build a familiarity with the small number of different custom rooms you could venture into, which to an extent, makes you feel like there's nothing new to discover and you've seen everything already. Just in a different order between the floors you take.Multiplayer is nonexistent online. I've tried searching for public matches and to no avail found any. So the multiplayer aspect would only be feesible if you had friends who also the game to play with and don't mind spending a vast amount of time on a playthrough that you can't save or return too. As of yet anyway. Overall...?Yes. It's a game that will entertain you for hours if you enjoy dungeon crawlers. Do not buy for the mulitplayer aspect, unless someone else owns the game and can be relied upon to play with you for hours at a time to even attempt to finish a playthrough. Atmospherics, music and gameplay is fairly good. Overal; buy this game when it's on sale. I wouldn't say it's worth the retail mark-up and it definitely needs a lot of rough edges smoothing out. Such as bugs and incomplete fixes. But a very promising arcade style game.

												The best implementation of a co-op Roguelike that I've seen. It mixes turn-based elements and real-time play, so that it's not one constant unbroken action sequence - you get downtime after each room unless you get overrun. The premise is simple: Open doors to explore the level, and beware of enemy spawns in unpowered rooms after you open each door. Find the exit, and carry your crystal from the entry point to it - but as soon as you pick it up, monsters will spawn until you escape.The lowest difficulty mode is tough, but reasonable - and there's one more above that if you're looking for a serious challenge. The descriptions of the items are humorous, the game is easy to understand, and offers a good challenge without being punishing. And it's fun on your own, but even moreso with up to three friends you can collaborate with. Highly recommended if you like Roguelikes and want to get your friends in on the action.

content:
y 6, 2015
												If you like FTL you'll like this game.  It has elements of a lot of different types of games:  4x, Rogue-like, Tower Defense, etc.    The goal is to escape the dungeon floor by floor.    Each floor starts the same way, you and a power source.    You need to explore until you find the exit.   Then you need to plan a way to move the power source to the exit.   Moving said power source spawns a neverending slew of monsters.   Monsters spawn from unpowered areas so you can set up an escape route.   All the while you need to balance leveling your team (Food), researching modules (Science) and building defenses or resource generating modules.   I'm 0 for 7 on "Too Easy" so expect a challenge.

content:
y 12, 2015
												I picked this up in a pack along with Endless Legend and Space because I wanted to get into a new 4x game. This game wasn't on my radar before and I didn't really expect anything from it. However what I found was a surprisingly addictive roguelike that borrowed elements from a dozen other genres put together into a deceptively complex whole. I've only beaten the game once on "easy" (actually the game's hard difficulty) but doing that took nearly a dozen attempts worth of familiarizing myself with the mechanics and each time felt unique and "worth" it.The game's art and music style are very nice and the heroes are interesting, if not in terms of personality at least what they bring to the table in terms of options available to you each run. I feel like they'd work well in a more fully fleshed out RPG setting with expanded mechanics.It would be nice if there was some kind of persistence between tries outside of which heroes you have unlocked to start with as I do feel that is a barrier to replayability currently. However even with that said I feel like this game is more than worth the admission price. One of the most surprisingly enjoyable games I've played recently.

content:
er 21, 2014
												This clever, nicely-paced game isn't quite FTL, but it's worth mentiong in the same sentence. FTL's basic gameplay is quite repetitive, but there are interesting choices to be made at the strategic level, as you find out what modules are on offer.  DOTE's basic gameplay has a fair amount of variation, but the number of viable strategies feels a lot more limited.  There's definitely a real learning curve, and unlocking character stories is quite satisfying.  However, DOTE feels much more like a series of tactical and operational puzzles than it gives a feeling of strategy.  I may be saying that because I haven't worked out the tactical puzzles yet (and am therefore blind to strategy) but there's a strong feeling of 'starting again' with each new floor that drains my sense of satisfaction and progression.If you like exploring mazes and unlocking things, you'll get a ton of enjoyment out of DOTE.  That's not quite my thing, but I still enjoyed it for quite a few hours.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
28, 2015
												It's an apt testimony to the skill and passion of the Amplitude folks that Dungeon of the Endless has become my go-to timewaster. The premise is simple: Your prison ship's been attacked and you've crash-landed on an uncharted planet. You and your motley band of inmates, ship staff and exotic natives must navigate the twelve floors of the mysterious dungeon you've found yourself in by finding the elevator on each floor and using the "crystal" generator from your escape pod to power it and move to the next level up. That crystal is also needed to power the rooms of the dungeon, providing a variety of resources conducive to your survival, but it is limited by its supply of "dust", and each room left unpowered has a chance to spawn a wave of hostile fauna whenever you open a new door on that floor.The gameplay is an elegant combination of roguelike, tower defence and classic RPG mechanics. It's both accessible and challenging, with a bit less of the luck factor of, say, FTL (you'll rarely be thrown into randomly unsurvivable situations) and more strategic decisions to make rather than a roll of the dice. While plotting your route through the dungeon, protecting the crystal is your primary concern. You'll have a range of modules to install in a dungeon, from resource generators to defensive weaponry, and as your power demand starts to exceed supply you'll have to get clever with which parts of the dungeon you keep powered and where you open new doors. Your heroes' abilities and attributes vary widely. Some are slow but powerful tanks, well-suited to holding a static position; others are technically-minded and can operate or repair the modules you build; others still are nimble speedsters ideal for responding to trouble spots or running the crystal to the elevator. Managing your heroes is therefore crucial to success.The understated soundtrack and the pseudo-pixellated, hand-painted graphics are both surpassingly beautiful, and taken with the game lore (which frequently ties in with that of Amplitude's other titles, Endless Space and Endless Legend) they create a truly unique atmosphere and sense of immersion. The heroes will treat you to some fun banter occasionally, and are great sources of emergent stories. The tale of how you brave robotic swordsman sacrificed himself keeping a horde of nasties from his beloved crystal carrier; or how two of your most dissimilar dungeon explorers form an unstoppable monster-slaying, best-buddy team; are experiences that remain with you long after their runs have ended. Some combinations of characters even have unique backstories of their own, which unfold as they ascend the floors with sometimes-shocking outcomes that I won't spoil here. Simply put, the game oozes personality.Whether you're a fan of the genre, or simply someone who appreciates an old-school challenge or a lovingly-made game, I can't recommend Dungeon of the Endless enough. Keep your eyes on Amplitude, because they've just had an amazing year.

content:
y 6, 2016
												A charming party roguelike and tower defence mashup. The basic idea is exploring rooms, protecting your generator from incoming mobs and then carrying your generator through the maze to the next level before the mobs get you. Works well. There's also manufacturing the resources familiar from Endless Space, but very simple. It can be harshly random in the manner roguelikes tend to be, but the game provides easy starting difficulties to compensate. For the replayability there's unlockable characters and game modes (landing pods).I can't resist making comparisons with SotS: The Pit even though these are fairly different games, The Pit being pure Roguelike. Both are still games with similar theme set in same respective universes as previous 4X space strategy games. Specifically, the different approach to the lore interests me. SotS has well constructed universe that is often explained with lots of text. Endless seems more haphazardly build, focusing more on overall feel rather than details. Filling in the blanks is left to the player if he wants them filled. I would say SotS is more like a novel while Endless is more like a painting of a landscape or and instrumental piece of music.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								It's alpha as all hell, the skill system needs to be implemented STAT, and there needs to be more variety to the core gameplay. While I understand that there needs to be a final, kill all failure (losing all dust), but make that a secondary worry, with the first being character survival and exploration. I say this mainly because I shouldn't need to step through a door, and have an inane worry of enemies flooding towards the crystal. That should be, if anything, a worst case scenario. While speaking of the crystal, implement more ways to obtain dust than unknowingly entering a room with a dust supply. It's a good thing this game is in bare-bones alpha, and still has much too look forward to. However, these are all minor complaints that WILL be filtered out or diverted in Dungeon's slow alpha-to-beta building process. The game already is good for just playing and relaxing. It doesn't require so much focus, you can't have other things at hand/in mind. Furthermore, I feel the game leaves plenty of room for an engaging story and style. People who played/enjoyed Endless Space, or more specifically, its lore will find this game intriguing enough. Perhaps wait 'til beta? I recommend it anyway but, don't jump on this bandwagon if you aren't planning on giving it time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 1, 2015
												An impressive game from the makers of Endless Legend and Endless Space, the links between the games are clear in the simple resources used in each, and the basic premises the games generally hold, as well as the subtle hints that ALL the games have links with one another that tease their fans; and the enticingly different games of each genre (if you can even define an exact genre for this one!) make their games distinctive and unique, a fresh breeze in genres that are frequently carbon copies of one design or another.Dungeon of the Endless does more than their previous efforts though - this time, it's not just a fresh take on a type of game, they've conjoined multiple genres and come up with something totally different. I would completely recommend it - it's both casually enjoyable, and surprisingly addictive. The simple graphics are not off-putting in the slightest, a testiment to the designers that they were aiming for gameplay far more than scoring 10/10 for being one-up on other developers (and the gorgeous graphics in their other games shows that they can definately deliver on that when they choose to)More than that though, they master the roguelike genre by giving you multiple unlockable bonuses for replaying, as well as gradually building your ability with the game; but not to a point where a seasoned, experienced player would always score FAR better than a new starter to it, so long as the new starter was prepared to learn from them.It's also fantastic for multiplayer, far more than many of the type, and the multiplayer is a totally different experience, one I'd recommend for anyone - though they may want to wait for the next release before doing it seriously with other people (save and load for multiplayer, bug-fixes, etc) - but I'd hasten to add that the solo play is hardly lacking either.Even when you think you've compeltely mastered an approach, a run of bad luck can leave you in a seriously dangerous position; and if the standard play begins to bore, switching the capsule type or the characters you play with totally changes how the game plays. A big thumbs up from me, and it further increases the respect I have for Ampitude's games as a whole.One last mention - they also have a quirky humour that's entirely their own, whether it comes to the fake latin-esque drugs on the infirmary pod to the in-game item descriptions and names; or simply in the tiny hints about their games and the secrets in them; or even in the lift conversations that unlock secrets in character biographies; all the hints and text are small and subtle, not requiring you to be involved; but if you want to put in the time to seek out their secrets, it's a satisfying reward for it too.A big congratulations from an experienced gamer to the developers - it's a lovely piece of work and makes me excited to see their next!

content:
3, 2014
Early Access Review
								(As of version Alpha 0.2.1) I picked up this game on a whim - it had the specs: indie, sci-fi, strategy, and fun art-direction.When I first picked it up, only the bare mechanics were in place. You took your heroes from room to room and tried to fight back the hordes going after your crystal. It was compelling then and with the features they continue to add, the game keeps getting more addictive. The idea is that a prison space ship crashes on an unknown planet. You need to direct your 'heroes' (guards and/or prisoners) to find the exit of the dungeon that they're stuck in. Each room will have doors. Every time you open a door you discover a new room which may have an item, a resource, or monsters. As you open more doors, you collect resourses and power which you can use to power/light-up rooms. Monsters will not appear in powered rooms while they could potentially show up in un-powered rooms. There are two phases to each level. The first phase is strategic exploration and tower defence: you can install turrets in your powered rooms to help your heroes fight the monsters. The second phase requires you to bring your crystal to the exit. It's a bit of a mad dash to the finish line. As you leave a room with the crystal, that room loses it's power supply. The two phases keep the levels fresh and keeps you planning ahead. If you enjoy strategy games, tower defence games, sci-fi, indie, elements of RPG, or like good pixel art then this game is for you! Even better, as they're still developing the game, more an more features are being added!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 7, 2014
												The only question I have is why I can't murder other heroes to loot them. The rest of my questions have all been killed out of me.I didn't think I'd like a roguelike this much. Maybe this and FTL have a secret hold on me. When it comes down to what you like about them, the challenge or the exploration, I think I like this game better as the challenge doesn't rely entirely on totallyrandom generation. Imagine if you could improve your ship in FTL without needingit all to come from shops or random encounters, but also gave you the options of directly influencing the parts of your ship with scrap, reinforcing the hull or weapons by themselves. That's what the heroesin this game fillthe gap on. Mixing it with tower defense makes this game engaging as you try tokeep heroes inbetween monsters and your crystal ala Dungeon Defenders, and executes it with the power sent to each grid. Managing these, your heroes and your defense network makes the game engaging.I would like to see more ships added. I enjoythe fact you can have certain gains and deficits granted by each pod, but if the developer doesn't make some whacky options available, or powerful ones, then the gimmick is short lived. I may be the only one who wants to see strange and fantastic options anymore, though. The excitement of seeing the doors open (as this is a door opening simulator, not a monster defense game as one would assume) is sadly reduced once you've run the gambit of monsters. I would like to see more happen.Gameplay: 9/10 Polished, well executed, and lacking in only the slightest of refinements. The stats lack descriptions and the tutorial hucks you in after a basic example.Story: 7/10 Must unlockthe characters and have them gab at one another for the story, but then again, that isn't what you came to do in this game, was it?Graphics: 8/10 Very pretty in game environments, monsters are varied but fit thesame subcategories, heroes continue to surpirse me in some ways. But the lit rooms sometimes offer little more than the dark ones did other than lack of gnawing death.Sound 9/10: As with games of this nature, sound effects are re-used oftenbut it doesn't grate the ears. Music is appropriate, well done, and generally pleasing.Overall: 9/10: Would open more doors.

												If you're into the rogue-like genre then this is a must get. There's a wide variety of characters and a lot of micro managing so I hope you're somewhat good with strategy games. You juggle three different resources and level up your characters to reach the end. There is a multiplayer aspect of the game that's quite interesting, but there's also major desync issues. You have to find them in a run and recruit them. You must then keep them alive for the next 3 floors. Doing so will allow you to pick them at the start of your run.Visuals: 9/10Gameplay: 10/10Controls: 7/10Replayability: 10/10

y 6, 2015
												If you like FTL you'll like this game.  It has elements of a lot of different types of games:  4x, Rogue-like, Tower Defense, etc.    The goal is to escape the dungeon floor by floor.    Each floor starts the same way, you and a power source.    You need to explore until you find the exit.   Then you need to plan a way to move the power source to the exit.   Moving said power source spawns a neverending slew of monsters.   Monsters spawn from unpowered areas so you can set up an escape route.   All the while you need to balance leveling your team (Food), researching modules (Science) and building defenses or resource generating modules.   I'm 0 for 7 on "Too Easy" so expect a challenge.

content:
ry 13, 2015
												An engrossing adventure that I can't put down.  Each turn is a combination of excitement and dread as another door is opened.  Guide your chosen heroes to their gruesome death again and again.  Just when it feel like it's getting easier and you have control of the situation, the RNG gods will test your defenses and most of the time crush them.  Do you make the risky play or the safe one?  Horde resources and build stronger defenses?  Make a run for the end of the level or open another door in search of resources?  Beautifully polished with endearing graphics and captivating music.  Oozing character and dark humour.  HIGHLY recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 21, 2014
												This clever, nicely-paced game isn't quite FTL, but it's worth mentiong in the same sentence. FTL's basic gameplay is quite repetitive, but there are interesting choices to be made at the strategic level, as you find out what modules are on offer.  DOTE's basic gameplay has a fair amount of variation, but the number of viable strategies feels a lot more limited.  There's definitely a real learning curve, and unlocking character stories is quite satisfying.  However, DOTE feels much more like a series of tactical and operational puzzles than it gives a feeling of strategy.  I may be saying that because I haven't worked out the tactical puzzles yet (and am therefore blind to strategy) but there's a strong feeling of 'starting again' with each new floor that drains my sense of satisfaction and progression.If you like exploring mazes and unlocking things, you'll get a ton of enjoyment out of DOTE.  That's not quite my thing, but I still enjoyed it for quite a few hours.

content:
16, 2015
												PROS-Diverse cast of misfits that you will lead to an inevitable demise.-Creates a wonderfully haunting sense of isolation through both the visual art style and the excellent soundtrack.-Somehow manages to blend tower defence, rts, rpg and roguelike elements together without failing at any of them.-Easy mode will ruthlessly murder your squad over and over again. -Different types of escape pods to unlock, each modifying how the game is played.-Pixellated pugs.NEUTRALS-This is definitely a roguelike, and sometimes you'll do as much as you can and still fail. Sometimes you will find the exit to the next floor in seven or eight rooms, sometimes it will be the last door on the floor. I find that being stretched thin and having to guard three fronts with a handful of turrets and heroes to be half the fun.CONS-An essential tactic for later in the game involves using heores in unpowered rooms in order to prevent enemy spawns. I'm not sure if this is mentioned anywhere in-game. I found out about it on the forums.I can't recommend this strongly enough. If you're a fan of any of the genres listed on the tags, do yourself a favour and pick this up.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 25, 2015
												The best implementation of a co-op Roguelike that I've seen. It mixes turn-based elements and real-time play, so that it's not one constant unbroken action sequence - you get downtime after each room unless you get overrun. The premise is simple: Open doors to explore the level, and beware of enemy spawns in unpowered rooms after you open each door. Find the exit, and carry your crystal from the entry point to it - but as soon as you pick it up, monsters will spawn until you escape.The lowest difficulty mode is tough, but reasonable - and there's one more above that if you're looking for a serious challenge. The descriptions of the items are humorous, the game is easy to understand, and offers a good challenge without being punishing. And it's fun on your own, but even moreso with up to three friends you can collaborate with. Highly recommended if you like Roguelikes and want to get your friends in on the action.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 17, 2015
What do I rate it? A significantly high 7/10.Why?In brief; it's an amazing dungeon crawler with a tower-defense aspect seamlessly and cleverly incorporated into the fighting aspect of the game between each round of opening a new random door. You could trawl the floors for hours and spend even longer over-thinking your strategic moves between rooms. After the fourth or fifth floor, you begin to feel a familiarity building and the game slowly becomes a little repetitive. Discovering the same rooms you did two floors ago - like a treasure room, banquet surprise (food bonus), scrap parts (factory parts) and yadda yadda. So although the maps are all unique and no path is the same as the last map, you begin to build a familiarity with the small number of different custom rooms you could venture into, which to an extent, makes you feel like there's nothing new to discover and you've seen everything already. Just in a different order between the floors you take.Multiplayer is nonexistent online. I've tried searching for public matches and to no avail found any. So the multiplayer aspect would only be feesible if you had friends who also the game to play with and don't mind spending a vast amount of time on a playthrough that you can't save or return too. As of yet anyway. Overall...?Yes. It's a game that will entertain you for hours if you enjoy dungeon crawlers. Do not buy for the mulitplayer aspect, unless someone else owns the game and can be relied upon to play with you for hours at a time to even attempt to finish a playthrough. Atmospherics, music and gameplay is fairly good. Overal; buy this game when it's on sale. I wouldn't say it's worth the retail mark-up and it definitely needs a lot of rough edges smoothing out. Such as bugs and incomplete fixes. But a very promising arcade style game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
r 21, 2015
												A very polished and very difficult dungeon crawler/roguelike/tower defense. The game flow is similar to Faster Than Light, but the mechanics are very different. So you basically do an action that advances the game, a random event is triggered (combat, loot, new hero, merchant, etc.), you have to react to it, manage your base and heroes according to the changes in the last round and then go for another round. The visuals are pretty nice and this is coming from someone who loathes gimmicky pixel art execution. Somehow the "modern" colors, lighting and 3D modeling of the dungeon blends really well with the 8-bit FX and character models.I would also add that DotE is a good example of Early Access done right - a solid concept, design and roadmap that materialized in a very stable and cohesive game.My only complaint is that none of the game's aspects is very complex, even if they seem to take a while to understand when put together. Character management is simplistic, combat is very basic, base management pretty much the same. The challenge actually comes from having to plan your moves well and using the least resources possible for the task, because one needs to stockpile for the toughest levels. Going too conservative on your resource usage results in an early loss, while not stockpiling enough results in a loss on the later levels.

content:
y 4, 2015
												A fantastic combination of tower defense with rpg and randomized elements. Each new pod you unlock changes the feel and play of the game to a great degree, making multiple playthroughs worthwhile, challenging and fun. Highly recommended.There is a definite learning curve, and it can take a few hours to get yourself going in a groove to get the feel for each unique escape pod's rules for success. The tutorial is lacking, but the guides aren't. If you're up for a challenge and the twoer defense and rogue like aspects are interesting to you, grab this. BE WARNED: the rogue-like aspects can mean you hit a floor you will need to play perfectly to beat, and you can lose a lot of progress for making a bad gamble. [and to some degree, the game can bone you with a punishing floor and there isn't much you can do if you get no dust (a type of currency) for like 9 rooms straight].

content:
y 18, 2016
												Holy fudgenuggets on a cheese biscuit, where do I even begin....Dungeon of the Endless (or as I call it, DotE) is a pixelated dungeon-crawler roguelike where you play as a ragtag group of people trying to escape from the pits of whatever kind of dungeon you fell into when your escape pod crashed. The thing about this game that makes it so much fun to play over and over again is... well, just about everything. Discovering new heroes, unlocking new ships, and discovering what each type of module does makes this game so much fun, and it's truly an enjoyable experience (also, the multiplayer is 10/10).So, if you're new at the game, let me close with this -  have fun, and please, for your sake, choose Sara and Gork for your first run. It's an amazing combo.

content:
ry 18
												When I first tried to play this game, I didn't like it. It seemed too complicated and I didn't understand what I was supposed to be doing. I let it sit for a while and then came back to it, and ended up loving it. Once you get the hang of the controls and a feel for how things work, it's a super fun and addicting game. The variety of characters to choose from and unlock and the range of ships you can play through all create different challenges that give it a lot of replayability. The characters are cool, the environment is cool, the music is good, the ambient sounds are creepy (but good). A solid game, would definitely recommend.
